chapter_title: The Human Eye and the Colourful World

Consider the role of ciliary muscles

questions.question_text: A person with a myopic eye cannot see objects beyond 1.2 m distinctly. What should be the type of the corrective lens used to restore proper vision?
hints: Consider lens type that diverges light

questions.question_text: What is the far point and near point of the human eye with normal vision?
hints: Distinguish between far and near points

questions.question_text: A student has difficulty reading the blackboard while sitting in the last row. What could be the defect the child is suffering from? How can it be corrected?
hints: Analyze the symptom: difficulty seeing distant objects

questions.question_text: The human eye can focus on objects at different distances by adjusting the focal length of the eye lens. This is due to (a) presbyopia. (b) accommodation. (c) near-sightedness. (d) far-sightedness.
hints: Recall definition from 'What you have learnt' section

questions.question_text: The human eye forms the image of an object at its (a) cornea. (b) iris. (c) pupil. (d) retina.
hints: Think about where image formation occurs

questions.question_text: The least distance of distinct vision for a young adult with normal vision is about (a) 25 m. (b) 2.5 cm. (c) 25 cm. (d) 2.5 m.
The change in focal length of an eye lens is caused by the action of the (a) pupil. (b) retina. (c) ciliary muscles. (d) iris.
